newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian metalworkers see no way out of strike.
newsitem.headline: Italian metalworkers see no way out of strike.

text.p: Italian metalworking unions said on Tuesday they saw no way of averting their planned eight-hour strike set for September 27 over the renewal of contracts.

"With things as they stand we don't think the strike can be avoided," Claudio Sabattini, leader of the FIOM trades union, told reporters. Labour Minister Tiziano Treu said on Monday that he thought there was still time to avert the stoppage.
"I don't know of any meetings planned at all or efforts on the part of the government to relaunch negotiations," he said.
Gianni Italia, leader of the FIM union, said he had no idea what was behind Treu's confidence.
Metalworking and engineering unions called the strike over the renewal of contracts for some 1.5 million engineer and metalworkers. Negotiations broke down earlier this month.
Unions have demanded an overall wage rise of 10.1 percent for their members over the next two years, while employers have offered between seven and nine percent.
If the stoppage goes ahead, it would be the sector's first nationwide strike over contracts since November 1990.
